I've used http://www.schwartzaccountants.com/ in Woburn for the past few years. The question is: why would you want to bank with an uncaring giant financial institution that puts your money into financing for large corporations? Bank with a small or smallish bank and you pay lower fees, get better customer service, and your money gets lent to small businesses and homeowners in your community.
I bank at Cambridge Savings, which isn't in JP or Brookline. You could use Brookline Bank or Wainwright.

WRITING.TEXT:
Lost in this discussion is the reason why we have jury duty: so that we, as citizens, have the right to be judged by our fellow citizens. Yes, it's extremely inconvenient to drop what you're doing and show up. But it's another one of those things (like voting) that are part of our democracy.
Like most rights, you may never need to exercise the right to a jury trial. But if you do, you'll be very glad that honest persons like yourself take the time out of their busy schedules to show up.
Don't know if they have it, but my go-to spot for obscure publications is Out of Town news in Harvard Square

The robots.txt exclusion is temporary, during the September 'free with registration' trial. Google doesn't like pages behind registration walls. Starting next month, Googlebot will be free to index - and stories found via Google will be free to read. (Disclaimer: I work for the Globe but my words are my own)

While you will have to pay to subscribe to BostonGlobe.com, links you find on Reddit (or Google, or Twitter, or Facebook...) will still let you read that article for free, once the free trial with registration period is over.
So if you want to snack on the news for free, you're welcome to. If you have the time and money for the full experience (and want to be able to save articles and read them offline across all your devices), we encourage you to pay.
(Disclaimer: I'm a product manager for the Globe)
Links from Reddit (and Google and Facebook and Twitter) will still be free after then.

WRITING.TEXT: This is probably too far away, but The Globe had a story yesterday on a family drum-making firm that started in the 1850s, made drums for Phil Collins, and is now getting by: http://www.boston.com/business/articles/2011/06/29/granville_drum_maker_endures_with_help_from_civil_war_replicas

Whitey was a mob boss in this town. Everyone knew it. He wasn't particularly smart, but he was particularly brutal. In 1995, the Globe discovered there was a reason why he had been successful: he was an FBI informant. And not only was he an FBI informant, having ratted out some of his rivals to the Feds, but the FBI was protecting him. There were years-long investigations which suddenly collapsed, after the FBI heard about the undercover work. Then, when Bulger is finally indicted, the FBI tips him off, and he hides out for 16 years.
Add to that the intriguing spice that his brother, Billy Bulger, was president of the Mass. State Senate -- an extremely important and powerful politician.
It's a great story. Read "Black Mass", or read some of the old Globe stories collected here: http://www.boston.com/news/specials/whitey/
I have never made anything from the cookbook, but everything I have eaten from the bakery was yummy. There are locations in Fort Point, the South End, and Cambridge.

I have banked at Cambridge Savings Bank for years. They have friendly, competent employees. Best of all, if you have enough money to have a "relationship savings" account with them, they refund up to $12/month in ATM fees. So you can use all those convenient Bank of America ATMs at least weekly and not have to worry about the fees.

WRITING.TEXT: When engineers started looking into the issue, they discovered that they had miscalculated the stress of wind on the building -- and it was in danger of falling over in a large storm. So they installed two 300-ton weights to be a "tuned mass damper", and reduce vibrations. Here's an interview with the caretaker: http://graphics.boston.com/news/special/audio_slideshows/hancock/mass_tune_damper/

Ditto to the Gardner. Not only do you get art, you get history, and a beautiful flower garden in the courtyard. It's easily accessible on the Green Line.
Outdoors is not going to be great in Boston in late March. It may be quite cold still. But take a walk along the Charles River esplanade for a classic Boston view. And then wander up into the historic streets of Beacon Hill.

WRITING.TEXT:
I'd say calling Jewishness an ethnicity is the closest description we have in America for people who share a common descent but whose nationality and citizenship is American.
As some of the other commenters have pointed out, Judaism is often expressed in America by the sorts of things that other ethnic groups do: food, outlooks, customs, common history. These are in addition to the religious rituals and beliefs

An MLS program is usually only two years. Most law schools are 3, doctors more.
As with any professional education, a lot of it is about setting people apart with abstruse knowledge. But there's also a lot of understanding how to organize information, knowing how to find stuff, management, and customer service.
